metadata.disclaimer: Based on publicly available crosswalks and expert analysis. Validate with qualified assessors for compliance/audit use.

clauses.title: Understanding the organization and its context
clauses.rationale: RA-3 covers risk context; PM-8/PM-11 cover mission/business process definition. ISO 27001 clause 4.1 requires broader organizational context analysis including external/internal issues beyond pure security risk.
clauses.gaps: No direct SP 800-53 control for analyzing external/internal issues (political, economic, social factors) affecting ISMS. Organizational context determination is broader than security risk assessment.

clauses.title: Understanding the needs and expectations of interested parties
clauses.rationale: PM-8 addresses critical infrastructure plan; PM-11 mission/business process definition; SR-1, SR-2, SR-3 address supply chain stakeholder relationships. These partially address stakeholder needs but ISO requires systematic identification of all interested parties and their requirements.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 lacks explicit requirement to identify all interested parties (regulators, customers, partners) and their specific ISMS expectations. Stakeholder mapping and requirements analysis not directly covered.

clauses.title: Determining the scope of the ISMS
clauses.rationale: PM-1 (information security program plan) and PM-10 (authorization process) help define boundaries. PM-7 helps identify system inventory. Scope definition is partially covered through system boundary concepts.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 defines system boundaries per authorization but doesn't explicitly require ISMS scope statement. Multi-system/enterprise scope determination differs from individual system authorization boundaries.

clauses.title: Information security management system
clauses.rationale: PM family establishes program-level controls. PM-1 defines program plan; PM-2 assigns roles; PM-3 covers resources; PM-6 measures effectiveness. Collectively these establish and maintain a security program.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 doesn't use PDCA/process approach terminology. Continuous improvement cycle and ISMS as a formal management system with documented processes is implicit rather than explicit.

clauses.title: Leadership and commitment
clauses.rationale: PM-1 requires senior official for security program; PM-2 assigns risk management roles; PM-13 addresses security workforce. Leadership accountability is addressed but ISO requires more explicit top management commitment.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 doesn't explicitly require top management to demonstrate commitment through resource allocation, communication of importance, or ensuring ISMS achieves intended outcomes.

clauses.title: Policy
clauses.rationale: PL-1 directly requires security planning policy with management approval. PM-1 requires information security program plan. Policy establishment, approval, and communication well covered.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifies policy must be 'appropriate to the purpose of the organization' and 'available as documented information' with specific distribution requirements.

clauses.title: Organizational roles, responsibilities, and authorities
clauses.rationale: PM-2 directly assigns information security responsibilities. PL-1 covers planning roles. PS-1 covers personnel security roles. Role assignment well covered in SP 800-53.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes that top management must ensure responsibilities are assigned and communicated. SP 800-53 focuses more on specific role assignments than organizational communication of roles.

clauses.title: Actions to address risks and opportunities
clauses.rationale: RA family directly addresses risk assessment. PM-9 covers risk management strategy. RA-3 is comprehensive risk assessment. Risk identification and treatment well covered.
clauses.gaps: ISO explicitly requires considering 'opportunities' alongside risks. SP 800-53 is risk-focused but doesn't explicitly address opportunities for improvement. Risk acceptance criteria less formalized.

clauses.title: Information security risk treatment
clauses.rationale: RA-3 covers risk assessment; PM-9 risk strategy; CA-5 plan of action and milestones for risk treatment. Risk treatment planning is well addressed.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires explicit Statement of Applicability (SoA) document. SP 800-53 doesn't have a direct SoA equivalent, though system security plans serve a similar purpose.

clauses.title: Information security objectives and planning to achieve them
clauses.rationale: PM-1 includes program objectives; PM-3 addresses resource planning; PM-6 covers security measures of performance. Objective-setting partially covered.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires measurable security objectives at relevant functions/levels with explicit plans (what, resources, responsible, completion, evaluation). SP 800-53 is less prescriptive about objective-setting methodology.

clauses.title: Planning of changes
clauses.rationale: CM-3 covers configuration change control; CM-4 impact analysis; SA-10 developer change management. Change planning well addressed from technical perspective.
clauses.gaps: ISO 6.3 is about planned changes to the ISMS itself (management system changes), not just technical changes. Organizational/process changes to the ISMS are not directly covered.

clauses.title: Resources
clauses.rationale: PM-3 directly addresses information security resources. SA-3 covers system development life cycle resources. Resource provision for security program covered.
clauses.gaps: ISO requirement is broader - all resources needed for ISMS establishment, implementation, maintenance, and continual improvement. Budget allocation and resource planning less prescriptive in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Competence
clauses.rationale: PM-13 directly addresses security workforce/competence. AT-2/AT-3 cover awareness and training. PM-16 covers threat awareness. Competence requirements well addressed.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires retaining documented evidence of competence (training records, certifications). While AT controls imply record-keeping, it's less explicit.

clauses.title: Awareness
clauses.rationale: AT-2 directly covers security awareness training including policy awareness, roles/responsibilities, and consequences. Very well aligned with ISO requirement.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. AT-2 covers awareness of policy, contribution to ISMS effectiveness, and implications of non-conformance.

clauses.title: Communication
clauses.rationale: PM-1 includes communication aspects of security program; PL-4 covers rules of behavior communication; IR-7 covers incident reporting communication.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires determining what, when, with whom, and how to communicate regarding ISMS. SP 800-53 lacks a systematic communication planning control. Internal/external communication strategy not explicitly required.

clauses.title: Documented information
clauses.rationale: PL-2 (system security plan) and PM-1 (program plan) address documentation. AU family covers audit records. Documentation requirements partially met.
clauses.gaps: ISO has specific requirements for documented information control (creation, updating, version control, distribution, access, storage, disposal). SP 800-53 doesn't have a unified document management control.

clauses.title: Operational planning and control
clauses.rationale: PL-2 covers system security plan implementation; PM-1 covers program implementation; CA-2 covers assessment of controls.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires organizations to plan, implement, and control processes needed to meet requirements. Outsourced process control and documented evidence of process execution are gaps.

clauses.title: Information security risk assessment
clauses.rationale: RA-3 directly covers risk assessment at planned intervals or when significant changes occur. RA-5 covers vulnerability assessment. Very well aligned.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. RA-3 comprehensively covers risk assessment execution, though ISO emphasizes retaining documented results.

clauses.title: Information security risk treatment
clauses.rationale: CA-5 (POA&M) addresses risk treatment plans. PM-4 tracks system-level plans. RA-3 includes risk response identification.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires retaining documented results of risk treatment. POA&M process is close but doesn't perfectly map to ISO risk treatment plan format.

clauses.title: Monitoring, measurement, analysis and evaluation
clauses.rationale: CA-7 (continuous monitoring) and PM-6 (measures of performance) directly address monitoring and measurement. SI-4 covers system monitoring.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires determining what to monitor, methods, when, who analyzes results. PM-6 is less prescriptive about evaluation methods and timing.

clauses.title: Internal audit
clauses.rationale: CA-2 covers security assessments (functionally equivalent to audits). CA-7 continuous monitoring. AU-6 audit review.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires formal internal audit program with defined criteria, scope, frequency, methods, and auditor independence. CA-2 covers assessments but doesn't use audit terminology or require audit program management.

clauses.title: Management review
clauses.rationale: PM-1 requires periodic program review; PM-6 covers performance measurement. These partially address management review.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifies detailed management review inputs (audit results, stakeholder feedback, risk assessment changes, opportunities for improvement) and outputs (decisions, resource changes). SP 800-53 lacks formal management review structure.

clauses.title: Continual improvement
clauses.rationale: CA-7 continuous monitoring supports improvement; PM-6 measures effectiveness; PM-1 includes program updates.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires explicit continual improvement processes for ISMS suitability, adequacy, and effectiveness. SP 800-53 supports continuous monitoring but doesn't explicitly require PDCA-style continual improvement methodology.

clauses.title: Nonconformity and corrective action
clauses.rationale: CA-5 (POA&M) addresses remediation of identified weaknesses. PM-4 tracks remediation plans.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires formal nonconformity management including root cause analysis, corrective action implementation, and effectiveness review. POA&M process is close but lacks formal nonconformity management structure.

clauses.title: Policies for information security
clauses.rationale: SP 800-53 has extensive policy controls (-1 controls) for every family. PL-1 is the overarching planning policy. PM-1 establishes program plan. Comprehensive policy framework.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 policy requirements are more granular (per-family) while ISO expects a coherent policy set.

clauses.title: Information security roles and responsibilities
clauses.rationale: PM-2 directly assigns senior information security role. PS-1 covers personnel security roles. Well addressed.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. ISO expects all security roles defined; SP 800-53 focuses on key roles.

clauses.title: Segregation of duties
clauses.rationale: AC-5 directly addresses separation of duties. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Management responsibilities
clauses.rationale: PM-2 covers management roles; PM-13 workforce management; PS-1 personnel policies. Management accountability addressed.
clauses.gaps: ISO emphasizes management requiring personnel to apply security per policies. SP 800-53 is less explicit about management enforcement responsibility.

clauses.title: Contact with authorities
clauses.rationale: IR-6 covers incident reporting to authorities. PM-15 covers contacts with security groups/associations.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes proactive relationship maintenance with authorities, not just incident reporting.

clauses.title: Contact with special interest groups
clauses.rationale: PM-15 directly covers contacts with security groups and associations. PM-16 covers threat awareness sharing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Threat intelligence
clauses.rationale: PM-16 addresses threat awareness program. SI-5 covers security alerts and advisories. RA-3/RA-5 include threat identification.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 is comprehensive on threat intelligence.

clauses.title: Information security in project management
clauses.rationale: SA-3 covers security in SDLC; SA-4 acquisition security requirements; PM-7 enterprise architecture.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically requires security in ALL project management regardless of project type. SA controls focus on system/software projects specifically.

clauses.title: Inventory of information and other associated assets
clauses.rationale: CM-8 directly covers system component inventory. PM-5 covers system inventory.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes 'information' assets and 'associated assets' (not just system components). Data inventory aspect less explicit.

clauses.title: Acceptable use of information and other associated assets
clauses.rationale: PL-4 directly covers rules of behavior / acceptable use. AC-20 covers use of external systems.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Return of assets
clauses.rationale: PS-4 covers personnel termination including return of organizational assets.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Classification of information
clauses.rationale: RA-2 covers security categorization of information and systems. Well aligned.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO uses classification levels; SP 800-53 uses FIPS 199 categorization. Conceptually similar but terminology/methodology differs.

clauses.title: Labelling of information
clauses.rationale: MP-3 covers media marking/labeling. RA-2 supports categorization for labeling.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO covers labeling of all information forms; MP-3 focuses on media.

clauses.title: Information transfer
clauses.rationale: SC-7 boundary protection; SC-8 transmission confidentiality/integrity; AC-4 information flow enforcement; AC-20 external system use.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes transfer agreements and policies for all forms (electronic, physical, verbal). SP 800-53 focuses on technical controls.

clauses.title: Access control
clauses.rationale: AC family is comprehensive. AC-1 policy; AC-2 account management; AC-3 access enforcement; AC-6 least privilege; AC-17 remote access.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 AC family is more detailed than ISO requirement.

clauses.title: Identity management
clauses.rationale: IA family comprehensively covers identification and authentication. IA-4 identifier management; IA-5 authenticator management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Authentication information
clauses.rationale: IA-5 directly covers authenticator management (passwords, tokens, etc.). IA-6 covers authenticator feedback.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Access rights
clauses.rationale: AC-2 covers account management including provisioning, review, and revocation. AC-6 covers least privilege.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information security in supplier relationships
clauses.rationale: SA-4 acquisition security requirements; SA-9 external system services; SR family covers supply chain risk.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes ongoing supplier relationship management and periodic review. SP 800-53 focuses more on acquisition-time requirements.

clauses.title: Addressing information security within supplier agreements
clauses.rationale: SA-4 directly requires security requirements in acquisitions. SA-9 covers service agreements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires specific agreement terms for information protection. SA-4 is comprehensive but format differs.

clauses.title: Managing information security in the ICT supply chain
clauses.rationale: SR family comprehensively addresses supply chain risk management including ICT supply chain.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 SR family is well aligned with ISO supply chain requirements.

clauses.title: Monitoring, review and change management of supplier services
clauses.rationale: SA-9 includes external service monitoring; SR-6 supplier assessments; CA-7 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires regular monitoring and review of supplier service delivery, change management of supplier services. SP 800-53 is less prescriptive about ongoing supplier service monitoring cadence.

clauses.title: Information security for use of cloud services
clauses.rationale: SA-9 covers external information system services (includes cloud); AC-20 external systems; SC-7 boundary protection.
clauses.gaps: ISO 27001:2022 added cloud-specific control. SP 800-53 addresses cloud through general external service controls but lacks cloud-specific acquisition, use, management, and exit requirements. FedRAMP supplements this.

clauses.title: Information security incident management planning and preparation
clauses.rationale: IR-1 covers incident response policy; IR-2 training; IR-3 testing; IR-8 incident response plan. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Assessment and decision on information security events
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling; IR-5 incident monitoring; IR-6 incident reporting. Well covered.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Response to information security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-4 comprehensively covers incident response. IR-6 reporting; IR-7 assistance.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Learning from information security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-3 includes lessons learned; IR-4 includes incident analysis. Post-incident review addressed.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes using incident knowledge to reduce future likelihood/impact systematically. SP 800-53 less prescriptive on knowledge management from incidents.

clauses.title: Collection of evidence
clauses.rationale: IR-4 includes evidence collection; AU-3 content of audit records; AU-6 audit review; AU-11 audit record retention.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO focuses on digital forensics evidence handling for legal proceedings. SP 800-53 covers audit records but evidence handling for legal admissibility less explicit.

clauses.title: Information security during disruption
clauses.rationale: CP family comprehensively covers continuity planning, testing, and recovery. Strong alignment.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: ICT readiness for business continuity
clauses.rationale: CP family covers IT contingency planning including alternate processing, telecommunications, recovery.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes ICT readiness specifically supporting business continuity plans. SP 800-53 focuses on IT contingency but connection to broader BCP is implicit.

clauses.title: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements
clauses.rationale: PL-4 includes compliance obligations; PM-1 addresses regulatory compliance; SA-4 contractual requirements.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires explicit identification and documentation of all legal/regulatory/contractual requirements. SP 800-53 lacks a dedicated legal compliance identification control. FISMA context assumes federal requirements.

clauses.title: Intellectual property rights
clauses.rationale: No direct SP 800-53 control for intellectual property management.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. SP 800-53 does not address software licensing, copyright compliance, or IP protection. Requires supplementary organizational controls.

clauses.title: Protection of records
clauses.rationale: AU-11 covers audit record retention; SI-12 covers information management and retention.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires protection of records from loss, destruction, falsification per legal/regulatory requirements. SP 800-53 covers retention but broader records management (classification, disposal schedules) less explicit.

clauses.title: Privacy and protection of PII
clauses.rationale: PT family (added in Rev 5) directly addresses privacy. PM-25 minimization; PM-26 complaint management; PM-27 privacy reporting.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO defers to ISO 27701 for full privacy coverage. SP 800-53 PT family is comprehensive for PII protection.

clauses.title: Independent review of information security
clauses.rationale: CA-2 covers security assessments which serve as independent reviews. CA-7 continuous monitoring; PM-6 performance measurement.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires independent review of the ISMS approach, not just technical control assessment. Management system review independence less explicit in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Compliance with policies, rules and standards
clauses.rationale: CA-2 assesses compliance; AU-6 reviews audit records for compliance; PM-6 measures performance.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires regular review that information processing complies with policies. SP 800-53 assessment approach differs from compliance checking methodology.

clauses.title: Documented operating procedures
clauses.rationale: PL-2 covers system security plans documenting procedures; SA-5 system documentation; CM-1 configuration management procedures.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires documented operating procedures for information processing facilities. SP 800-53 has family-specific procedures but no unified operating procedures control.

clauses.title: Screening
clauses.rationale: PS-3 directly covers personnel screening before access is granted.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Terms and conditions of employment
clauses.rationale: PS-6 covers access agreements; PL-4 covers rules of behavior. Employment terms for security covered.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes security responsibilities in employment contracts. SP 800-53 focuses on access agreements rather than employment contract terms.

clauses.title: Information security awareness, education and training
clauses.rationale: AT-2 awareness training; AT-3 role-based training; AT-4 training records; PM-13 workforce program. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Disciplinary process
clauses.rationale: PS-8 covers personnel sanctions for security violations.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires formal disciplinary process communicated to employees. PS-8 addresses sanctions but formal process establishment less detailed.

clauses.title: Responsibilities after termination or change of employment
clauses.rationale: PS-4 covers personnel termination; PS-5 covers personnel transfer. Both address ongoing responsibilities.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. PS-4/PS-5 address access revocation and ongoing obligations.

clauses.title: Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements
clauses.rationale: PS-6 covers access agreements which include confidentiality requirements.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically requires NDAs reflecting organizational needs. PS-6 is broader (access agreements) and NDA specifics are less detailed.

clauses.title: Remote working
clauses.rationale: AC-17 directly covers remote access controls. PE-17 covers alternate work sites.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes remote working security policies and risk considerations beyond technical access controls (physical environment, clean desk at home).

clauses.title: Information security event reporting
clauses.rationale: IR-6 directly covers incident reporting. IR-7 covers incident response assistance.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Physical security perimeters
clauses.rationale: PE-3 covers physical access control; PE-4 covers access control for transmission medium.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Physical entry
clauses.rationale: PE-2 physical access authorizations; PE-3 physical access control; PE-6 monitoring; PE-8 visitor access records.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Comprehensive physical entry controls.

clauses.title: Securing offices, rooms and facilities
clauses.rationale: PE-3 physical access control; PE-5 access control for output devices.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes broader facility security design considerations.

clauses.title: Physical security monitoring
clauses.rationale: PE-6 directly covers monitoring physical access. PE-8 access logs.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Protecting against physical and environmental threats
clauses.rationale: PE family comprehensively covers environmental protections: power (PE-9,11), fire (PE-13), temperature (PE-14), water (PE-15).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Working in secure areas
clauses.rationale: PE-2/PE-3 control access; PE-7 addresses visitor control in secure areas.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes rules for working in secure areas (no cameras, supervised work). SP 800-53 less specific about behavioral controls in secure areas.

clauses.title: Clear desk and clear screen
clauses.rationale: AC-11 covers session lock (clear screen). MP-4 covers media storage.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO explicitly addresses clear desk policy. AC-11 covers screen; desk policy is implied through MP controls but not explicitly stated.

clauses.title: Equipment siting and protection
clauses.rationale: PE-14 covers environmental controls; PE-18 location of components. General equipment protection covered.
clauses.gaps: ISO includes equipment placement to minimize unauthorized access and environmental hazards. SP 800-53 less specific about equipment siting methodology.

clauses.title: Security of assets off-premises
clauses.rationale: AC-17 remote access; MP-5 media transport; SC-28 protection of information at rest.
clauses.gaps: ISO covers all off-premises assets (laptops, paper, etc.). SP 800-53 covers media and remote access but physical asset protection off-site less comprehensive.

clauses.title: Storage media
clauses.rationale: MP family comprehensively covers media protection: policy (MP-1), access (MP-2), marking (MP-3), storage (MP-4), transport (MP-5), sanitization (MP-6), use (MP-7).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Supporting utilities
clauses.rationale: PE-9 power equipment protection; PE-10 emergency shutoff; PE-11 emergency power; PE-12 emergency lighting.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Cabling security
clauses.rationale: PE-4 covers access control for transmission medium. PE-9 covers power equipment/cabling protection.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes specific cabling security measures (protected routing, shielding). PE-4 is more general.

clauses.title: Equipment maintenance
clauses.rationale: MA family comprehensively covers maintenance: policy (MA-1), controlled maintenance (MA-2), tools (MA-3), nonlocal (MA-4), personnel (MA-5), timely (MA-6).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
clauses.rationale: MP-6 covers media sanitization; MP-7 covers media use restrictions.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes all equipment disposal; SP 800-53 focuses on media specifically.

clauses.title: User endpoint devices
clauses.rationale: AC-19 covers access control for mobile devices; CM-7 least functionality; SC-28 protection at rest.
clauses.gaps: ISO covers all user endpoint devices holistically (BYOD, MDM, containerization). SP 800-53 addresses mobile and device management across multiple controls but no unified endpoint control.

clauses.title: Privileged access rights
clauses.rationale: AC-6 directly covers least privilege. AC-2(7) addresses privileged account management. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information access restriction
clauses.rationale: AC-3 access enforcement; AC-4 information flow enforcement; AC-6 least privilege.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Access to source code
clauses.rationale: CM-5 covers access restrictions for change; AC-3 access enforcement; SA-10 developer configuration management.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses source code access restrictions. SP 800-53 addresses through configuration management and access controls.

clauses.title: Secure authentication
clauses.rationale: IA-2 identification and authentication; IA-5 authenticator management; IA-8 non-organizational users; IA-11 re-authentication.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Capacity management
clauses.rationale: AU-4 covers audit log storage capacity; SC-5 denial of service protection; CP-2 contingency planning considers capacity.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires proactive capacity management for all IT resources. SP 800-53 addresses capacity in specific contexts but lacks a general capacity planning control.

clauses.title: Protection against malware
clauses.rationale: SI-3 directly covers malicious code protection. SI-8 covers spam protection.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Management of technical vulnerabilities
clauses.rationale: RA-5 vulnerability monitoring and scanning; SI-2 flaw remediation; SI-5 security alerts.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Configuration management
clauses.rationale: CM family comprehensively covers configuration management: baselines (CM-2), change control (CM-3), analysis (CM-4), settings (CM-6), least functionality (CM-7).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information deletion
clauses.rationale: MP-6 media sanitization; SI-12 information management/retention.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses information deletion when no longer required. SP 800-53 covers sanitization and retention but proactive deletion based on business need less explicit.

clauses.title: Data masking
clauses.rationale: SI-19 covers de-identification. PT-6/PT-7 cover data processing minimization.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses data masking techniques (pseudonymization, anonymization, masking). SP 800-53 Rev 5 added privacy controls but masking as a technique is less comprehensively addressed.

clauses.title: Data leakage prevention
clauses.rationale: AC-4 information flow enforcement; SC-7 boundary protection; SI-4 system monitoring; PE-19 information leakage.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses DLP. SP 800-53 covers information flow and monitoring but integrated DLP as a concept is distributed across multiple controls.

clauses.title: Information backup
clauses.rationale: CP-9 directly covers information system backup. CP-6 alternate storage site.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Redundancy of information processing facilities
clauses.rationale: CP-6 alternate storage; CP-7 alternate processing site; CP-8 telecommunications services.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO focuses on redundancy for availability. CP controls focus on contingency which includes redundancy.

clauses.title: Logging
clauses.rationale: AU family comprehensively covers logging: events (AU-2), content (AU-3), storage (AU-4), response (AU-5), review (AU-6), reporting (AU-7), timestamps (AU-8), protection (AU-9), retention (AU-11).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Monitoring activities
clauses.rationale: SI-4 directly covers system monitoring. AU-6 audit review; CA-7 continuous monitoring; IR-4 incident handling.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Clock synchronization
clauses.rationale: AU-8 directly covers time stamps and clock synchronization.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Use of privileged utility programs
clauses.rationale: CM-7 least functionality restricts utilities; CM-11 user-installed software; AC-6 least privilege.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses privileged utility programs. SP 800-53 addresses through general controls.

clauses.title: Installation of software on operational systems
clauses.rationale: CM-5 access restrictions for change; CM-7 least functionality; CM-11 user-installed software; SA-22 unsupported components.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Networks security
clauses.rationale: SC-7 boundary protection; SC-8 transmission confidentiality/integrity; AC-4 information flow.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Security of network services
clauses.rationale: SC-7/SC-8 cover network security. SA-9 covers external system services including network services.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires security features, service levels, and management requirements for network services. Service level specifics less detailed in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Segregation of networks
clauses.rationale: SC-7 boundary protection with segmentation. SC-32 system partitioning.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Web filtering
clauses.rationale: SC-7 boundary protection includes filtering; SI-3 malware protection; AC-4 information flow.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses web filtering. SP 800-53 doesn't have a dedicated web filtering control; addressed through general boundary and content controls.

clauses.title: Use of cryptography
clauses.rationale: SC-12 cryptographic key management; SC-13 cryptographic protection; SC-28 protection of information at rest.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 cryptography controls are comprehensive.

clauses.title: Secure development life cycle
clauses.rationale: SA-3 system development life cycle; SA-8 security engineering; SA-10 developer config management; SA-11 developer testing; SA-15 development process/standards; SA-17 developer security architecture.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 SA family is comprehensive for secure development.

clauses.title: Application security requirements
clauses.rationale: SA-4 acquisition process / security requirements in acquisitions. SA-8 security engineering principles.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure system architecture and engineering principles
clauses.rationale: SA-8 security engineering principles; SA-17 developer security architecture; SC-7/SC-32 architecture-level controls.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure coding
clauses.rationale: SA-11 developer security testing; SA-15 development process standards; SA-16 developer-provided training; SA-17 security architecture.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses secure coding practices. SP 800-53 addresses through development process and testing controls rather than explicit coding standards.

clauses.title: Security testing in development and acceptance
clauses.rationale: SA-11 directly covers developer security testing. CA-2 security assessments. SA-4 includes testing requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Outsourced development
clauses.rationale: SA-4 acquisition requirements; SA-9 external system services; SA-10/SA-11 developer requirements apply to outsourced development.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses outsourced development supervision and acceptance. SP 800-53 covers through general acquisition controls.

clauses.title: Separation of development, test and production environments
clauses.rationale: CM-4 impact analysis (separate test environments); SA-11 developer testing environment; SC-32 system partitioning.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO explicitly requires environment separation. SP 800-53 implies it through testing and partitioning controls but doesn't mandate specific environment separation.

clauses.title: Change management
clauses.rationale: CM-3 configuration change control; CM-4 impact analysis; CM-5 access restrictions for change; SA-10 developer configuration management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Test information
clauses.rationale: SA-11 covers testing. SA-15 development process standards.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses protection of test data (anonymization, controlled access to production data used in testing). SP 800-53 lacks explicit test data management control.

clauses.title: Protection of information systems during audit testing
clauses.rationale: CA-2 covers security assessments including audit considerations. AU-6 audit review analysis.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires that audit testing be planned and agreed to minimize business disruption. SP 800-53 assessment controls don't explicitly address protection of systems during audit activities.
